P.title: Will we reach the island of stability by 2050?
P.body: The question will resolve as Yes if, by January 1, 2050, a peer-reviewed scientific publication confirms the creation and identification of an isotope that is part of the theorized island of stability in the periodic table of elements. The isotope must exhibit a half-life of at least one minute, which is significantly longer than the half-lives of surrounding elements that are not considered stable. The publication must be recognized by the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC) or an equivalent authoritative body in the field of chemistry or nuclear physics. In the event that the IUPAC or its equivalent is no longer operational or recognized as an authoritative body, a consensus among at least five leading experts in the field, from at least three different countries, will be required to confirm the discovery. If no such isotope is confirmed by the resolution date, the question will resolve as No.

para_P.title: By 2050, will scientists have confirmed the existence of an isotope within the predicted island of stability?
para_P.body: This question will be resolved as Yes if, by the 1st of January 2050, a peer-reviewed scientific paper has verified the discovery and identification of an isotope belonging to the hypothesized island of stability on the periodic table. The isotope must demonstrate a half-life of at least one minute, significantly exceeding the half-lives of nearby unstable elements. The paper must be acknowledged by the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC) or a similar reputable authority in chemistry or nuclear physics. Should the IUPAC or its equivalent cease to exist or be recognized as an authoritative entity, the confirmation must come from a consensus among at least five top experts in the field from a minimum of three different countries. If such an isotope is not confirmed by the specified date, the question will resolve as No.

P.title: Will gravitational waves from the merger of supermassive black holes be detected by November 30, 2027?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, by November 30, 2027, there is a confirmed detection of gravitational waves originating from the merger of supermassive black holes. The detection must be confirmed by at least one of the following authoritative sources: LIGO Scientific Collaboration, Virgo Collaboration, or an equivalent scientific body recognized for gravitational wave astronomy. The detection must be published in a peer-reviewed scientific journal and must specify that the waves are a result of supermassive black holes merging. In the event of conflicting reports or inconclusive evidence by the resolution date, the question will resolve as No. If no detection is reported by the resolution date, the question will also resolve as No.

If there are conflicting reports or the evidence remains inconclusive by the deadline, or if no detection has been reported, the question will resolve as No.

P.title: Will there be more VR headset sales than AR headsets sales in 2025?
P.body: This question will resolve as Yes if, according to the cumulative sales data reported by the International Data Corporation (IDC) or a similar authoritative market research firm, the total number of virtual reality (VR) headsets sold globally in the year 2025 exceeds the total number of augmented reality (AR) headsets sold in the same period. Sales figures must be specific to VR and AR headsets and not include other wearable devices. In the event that the IDC or equivalent authoritative source does not report the required data by the resolution date, the question will resolve using the most credible data available from major technology market analysis firms. If no such data is available by the resolution date, the question will resolve as ambiguous.

Should the IDC or a similar authoritative entity fail to report by the resolution date, the question will be settled using the most reliable data available from leading technology market analysts.
